leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 122] s 122 Rules taken to have effect as rules made by the Rule Committee

leg:heading.title: Rules taken to have effect as rules made by the Rule Committee

p.text: The rules in the Fourth Schedule to this Act shall come into operation on the commencement of this Act, but subject to and together with rules made by the Rule Committee.

Upon the expiry of six months after the commencement of this Act, or on such earlier date as may be appointed by the Governor and notified by proclamation published in the Gazette, the Fourth Schedule to this Act shall, by force of this subsection, be repealed.

On and after the repeal to be effected by subsection (2) the rules in the Fourth Schedule to this Act shall have effect as rules made by the Rule Committee, but subject to and together with rules made by the Rule Committee.
A proclamation was not published under subsection (2). Therefore, the Fourth Schedule was repealed on 1 January 1973 (six months after the commencement of this Act).
[s 122 am Act 93 of 2000 Sch 2]
Rules may be made under this Act by a Rule Committee consisting of—
the Chief Justice;
the President of the Court of Appeal or a Judge of Appeal appointed on the nomination of the President of the Court of Appeal;
one other appointed Judge of Appeal.
four other appointed judges; and
an appointed barrister and an appointed solicitor.
[subs (1) am Act 41 of 1972 s 11 ; Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]
In this section, “appointed” means appointed to the Rule Committee by the Chief Justice by instrument in writing.
[subs (2) am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]
In this section and in section 123A :
has the same meaning as in the Legal Profession Act 2004 .
[def subst Act 120 of 2006 s 3 and Sch 3[3.25] , effective 4 December 2006]
has the same meaning as in the Legal Profession Act 2004 .
[def subst Act 120 of 2006 s 3 and Sch 3[3.25] , effective 4 December 2006]
[subs (2A) insrt Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 1]
A person appointed shall hold office for the time specified in the appointment but may resign by instrument in writing addressed to the Chief Justice.
[subs (3) am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]
At a meeting of the Rule Committee the chairman shall be—
the Chief Justice, if the Chief Justice is present;
if the Chief Justice is not present but the President of the Court of Appeal is a member of the Rule Committee and is present, the President of the Court of Appeal; or
in the absence of the Chief Justice and the President of the Court of Appeal, one of the members present, chosen by the meeting.
[subs (4) am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]
In the case of equality of voting, the chairman shall have a casting as well as a deliberative vote.
Any four members of the Rule Committee shall constitute a quorum.
There shall be a secretary of the Rule Committee who shall be a person approved by the Chief Justice.
Subject to this section, the Rule Committee may regulate its own procedure.
[subs (8) insrt Act 41 of 1972 s 11]

The Rule Committee may, if it thinks fit, transact any of its business by the circulation of papers among all the members of the Rule Committee for the time being, and a resolution in writing approved in writing by a majority of those members is to be taken to be a decision of the Rule Committee.
[subs (9) insrt Act 108 of 1990 s 3 and Sch 1]

A person who, as a purported member, attended a meeting of the Rule Committee held on or after 1 July 2005 and before 1 July 2007 is taken to have been a duly appointed member of the Rule Committee during that time and accordingly any rule that was purportedly made by the Rule Committee during that time is taken to have been duly made.
[subs (10) insrt Act 56 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 8[4], effective 15 November 2007]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 123A] s 123A Deputies for barrister and solicitor members

leg:heading.title: Deputies for barrister and solicitor members

p.text: The Chief Justice may, from time to time, appoint to the Rule Committee:
a barrister to be the deputy of the barrister member appointed under section 123(1)(e) ; and
a solicitor to be the deputy of the solicitor member appointed under section 123(1)(e) ,
and the Chief Justice may revoke any such appointment.
In the absence of a member appointed under section 123(1)(e) , the member's deputy:
may, if available, act in the place of the member; and
while so acting, has the functions of the member and is taken to be the member.
[s 123A insrt Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 2]

Any rules may be altered or added to or rescinded, and any further or additional rules may be made, by the Rule Committee for the purpose of carrying this Act into effect and, without limiting the generality of the foregoing, for the following purposes—

for regulating and prescribing the procedure (including the method of pleading) and the practice to be followed in the Court in all proceedings in, or with respect to which, the Court has for the time being jurisdiction (including the procedure and practice to be followed in the offices of the Court), and any matters incidental to, or relating to, any such procedure or practice, including the manner and time of making any applications which under this or any other Act, or under any Imperial Act or Commonwealth Act, are to be made to the Court;

for regulating and prescribing the form and contents of any case stated to the Court by or from any court or person and the time within which and the manner in which proceedings thereon are to be instituted in the Court and the practice and procedure thereafter to be followed in the Court and the notification of the decision of the Court;

for regulating and prescribing the practice and procedure to be followed in connection with the institution of any appeal from any inferior court or from any person to the Court, including the time within which, and the manner in which, the appeal is to be instituted, and the practice and procedure thereafter to be followed in the Court;

for regulating and prescribing the practice and procedure to be followed in connection with the transfer of any proceedings from any inferior court, and for the co-ordination or expedition of any such transfers, and, where proceedings are transferred to the Court, the practice and procedure thereafter to be followed in the Court;

for regulating and prescribing any matter which, under any Act, or Imperial Act may be regulated or prescribed by rules of the Court or by rules made by the Judges or any Judges or the Chief Judge in Equity or any other Judge identified by description of his or her office or the Judges of Appeal or any Judges of Appeal;

for altering, adding to or rescinding any rules in force immediately before the commencement of this Act, which regulate or prescribe any matter which, under any Act, or Imperial Act might, immediately before the commencement of this Act, be regulated or prescribed by rules of the Court or by rules made by the Judges or any Judges or the Chief Judge in Equity or any other Judge identified by description of his or her office or the Judges of Appeal or any Judges of Appeal;
for providing for the regulation of the sittings and order of business of the Court and the regulation of the vacations and holidays to be observed by the Court and in the offices of the Court;
for prescribing what powers of the Court may be exercised by any of the associate Judges, acting associate Judges, registrars and other officers of the Court;
[repealed]

for regulating any matters relating to the costs of proceedings in the Court and, in particular, prescribing, limiting or otherwise affecting the costs recoverable in any action or proceedings that the Court considers might properly have been dealt with in an inferior court;
[repealed]
[repealed]
for prescribing means for, and the practice and procedure to be followed in, the enforcement and execution of judgments and orders;

for regulating the means by which particular facts may be proved, and the mode in which evidence may be given (including the administration of oaths to and the taking of the evidence of witnesses in or out of New South Wales), in any proceedings, or on any application in connection with, or at any stage of, any proceedings;

for prescribing matters relating to expert evidence, including the disclosure, by the furnishing of copies of reports or otherwise, of the nature of expert evidence to be given, and including the exclusion of expert evidence in case of non-compliance with the rules relating to expert evidence or with any order for disclosure of the nature of expert evidence;
for prescribing the cases in which security may be required, and the form of such security, and the manner in which, and the person to whom, it is to be given;
for regulating and prescribing any matter concerning or in relation to which provision was made by the rules set out in the Fourth Schedule to this Act when it commenced,
[repealed]
[repealed]
for regulating the payment or transfer into or out of Court and, subject to the consent of the Treasurer, the custody, management and investment of moneys, securities and effects; and
for prescribing and regulating the duties of the associate Judges, acting associate Judges, registrars and other officers of the Court in relation to or for the purpose of any proceedings.
[repealed]

[subs (1) am Act 41 of 1972 s 11 ; Act 205 of 1979 s 5 ; Act 54 of 1984 s 3 ; Act 111 of 1987 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 138 of 1989 s 4 and Sch 7 ; Act 12 of 1991 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3 ; Act 87 of 1993 s 4 and Sch 6 ; Act 57 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 58 of 1997 s 4 and Sch 2 ; Act 93 of 2000 Sch 2 ; Act 71 of 2003 s 3 and Sch 8, effective 1 January 2004 s 21 ; Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005; Act No 28 of 2005, effective 15 August 2005]
The rules may make provision for or with respect to—

the cases in which the whole of any proceedings or any question or issue arising in any proceedings may be referred by the Court to an arbitrator or referee for determination or for inquiry and report;
the appointment of a Judge, associate Judge, registrar or other officer of the Court or other person as an arbitrator or referee;
the fees to be paid to such an arbitrator or referee;
the persons by whom the whole or any part of any such fees are payable;
the consequences of a determination or report by an arbitrator or referee;
the manner in which such a determination or report may be called in question;
whether or not, or to what extent, a determination or report may be called in question on a matter of fact or law;

the provision of the services of officers of the Court and the provision of court rooms and other facilities for the purpose of a reference of any proceedings or any question or issue arising in any proceedings to an arbitrator or referee; and
any other matters associated with such a reference.
[subs (2) insrt Act 166 of 1984 s 3 and Sch 1 ; am Act 218 of 1986 s 3 and Sch 47 ; Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]

The rules may make provision for or with respect to the assignment of proceedings to the Court of Appeal or a Division. The assignment by the rules of any proceedings to the Court of Appeal or any Division has effect despite any contrary provision of this or any other Act or law.
[subs (3) insrt Act 172 of 1998 s 3 and Sch 10]

The rules may authorise an associate Judge to punish contempt in the face of the Court or in the hearing of the Court where the Court is constituted by that associate Judge and to punish the breach of an undertaking given to the Court constituted by that associate Judge, but otherwise the rules shall not authorise an associate Judge, registrar or other officer to make an order for the committal, attachment or arrest of any person.
[subs (4) am Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005]
Where the rules rescind a rule by which a previous rule was rescinded, then, unless the contrary intention appears, the previous rules shall not be revived.
[subs (5) am Act 93 of 2000 Sch 2]

Where the rules rescind or amend a previous rule, then, unless the contrary intention appears, the rescission or amendment shall not revive anything not in force or existing immediately before the rescission or amendment takes effect.
[subs (6) am Act 93 of 2000 Sch 2]

After the commencement of this Act no power by any Act or Imperial Act conferred upon the Judges or any Judge or the Chief Judge in Equity or any other Judge identified by description of his or her office or the Judges of Appeal or any Judges of Appeal to make rules as to any matter shall be exercised otherwise than by the Rule Committee making in respect of that matter rules under and in accordance with this Act.
[subs (7) am Act 41 of 1972 s 11 ; Act 205 of 1979 s 5 ; Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]

Rules made by the Rule Committee under this Act shall, so far as inconsistent with rules made (whether before or after the commencement of this Act) under any other Act, or under any Imperial Act, prevail over the latter rules while the inconsistency exists.
[subs (8) am Act 41 of 1972 s 11]
This section does not give power to make rules with respect to any matter with respect to which rules may be made under section 28 or 38(4) of the Legal Profession Act 2004.
[subs (9) am Act 41 of 1972 s 11 ; Act 92 of 1988 s 3 and Sch 26 ; Act 98 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 3.49, effective 24 November 2005]
This section does not give power to make rules with respect to any matter relating to costs that is regulated by Part 3.2 of the Legal Profession Act 2004.
[subs (10) insrt Act 87 of 1993 s 4 and Sch 6; am Act 98 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 3.49, effective 24 November 2005]

This section does not give power to make rules in terms inconsistent with those of the uniform rules under the Civil Procedure Act 2005 unless the uniform rules expressly permit rules under this section to be made on those terms.
[subs (10A) insrt Act No 28 of 2005, effective 15 August 2005]

The rules made under this section may authorise or require the use of an electronic case management system established under clause 2 of Schedule 1 to the Electronic Transactions Act 2000 in relation to any proceedings in a court in respect of which the use of such a system is authorised by an order in force under clause 3 of Schedule 1 to that Act.
[subs (10B) insrt Act No 28 of 2005, effective 15 August 2005 ; am Act 119 of 2010 Sch 2.39, effective 7 January 2011]

The rules made under thsi section may provide for the exercise by a registrar or other officer of the Court of any of the Court's administrative or judicial functions under this or any other Act and for the review by the Court of the exercise by a registrar or other such officer of any such function.
[subs (10C) insrt Act No 28 of 2005, effective 15 August 2005]

A practice note (including any other document, however described, which regulates the practice or procedure of the Court, any Division of the Court or of any class of proceedings in the Court, but excluding a decision of the Court) issued by or on behalf of the Court must be published in the Gazette.
[subs (11) insrt Act 87 of 1993 s 4 and Sch 6 ; am Act 56 of 2009 Sch 4.71[3], effective 17 July 2009]
Sections 40 and 41 of the Interpretation Act 1987 apply to a practice note in the same way as they apply to a statutory rule.
[subs (12) insrt Act 56 of 2009 Sch 4.71[4], effective 17 July 2009]
A proclamation was not published pursuant to this subsection.
Section 4 of the Supreme Court (Commercial Arbitration) Amendment Act No 166 of 1984 provides as follows:
Where—

any proceedings were or any questions or issue of fact arising in the proceedings was, under section 15 of the Arbitration Act 1902 ordered by the Supreme Court to be tried before an arbitrator or referee before the commencement of this section; or
no rules of court have been made under section 124(2) of the Supreme Court Act 1970, as inserted by this Act,

the law governing the reference by the Supreme Court of any proceedings in that court or any question or issue of fact arising in the proceedings to an arbitrator or referee shall be that which would have been applicable if this Act and the Commercial Arbitration Act 1984 , had not been enacted.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 124.5] The relationship between the rule making power and substantive law

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 124.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 124(1)(ma).
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 (o).

heading.title: The relationship between the rule making power and substantive law

p.text: Apart from specific provisions, such as s 124(1)(ma) or (o) , the general rule making power does not authorise rules which would result in changes to substantive rules of law: General Mediterranean Holdings (SA) v Patel [1999] 3 All ER 673 (no departure from a right of confidentiality under the general law).
Legislation cited in [SCA s 124.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Interpretation Act 1987 ss 40, 41.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 Pt 1 r 1, r 12.

Interpretation Act 1987 ss 40 and 41 require statutory rules (including Practice Notes) to be tabled before, and renders them liable to disallowance by, parliament. Practice Notes are issued under the authority of the court, usually signified by the signature of the Chief Justice and must be published in the NSW Gazette. They are issued by the Rule Committee and are not rules of court. Practice Notes are clearly important in influencing the practice and procedures of the court. However, they should be read in conjunction with, and ultimately recognising the authority of, the rules of the court, including the flexible discretions conferred by SCR Pt 1 r 1 and r 12 : Baulderstone Hornibrook Pty Ltd v HBO & DC Pty Ltd [2001] NSWSC 821; BC200105624 at [14] (emphasises that summary judgment applications will usually not be entertained for proceedings in the Commercial List).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 125] s 125 Arrangements for exchange of information between Court and foreign courts

leg:heading.title: Arrangements for exchange of information between Court and foreign courts

p.text: Rules may be made under this Act, or under the Civil Procedure Act 2005, for or with respect to:

the referral by the Court of a question as to the principles of foreign law, or their application, to a foreign court for information, advice or assistance (with or without the consent of parties to proceedings), and
the provision by the Court, to a foreign court, of information, advice or assistance on a question as to the principles of Australian law, or their application.
In this section:
means a court of a country other than Australia.
means the law of a country other than Australia.
[s 125 insrt Act 135 of 2010 Sch 17, effective 7 December 2010]

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 125.5] Foreign law — referral under UCPR r 20.14

heading.title: Foreign law — referral under UCPR r 20.14

p.text: The provisions of UCPR Pt 6 Div 9 contain rules relating to the commencement of proceedings involving disputed questions of foreign law. Under those provisions disputed issues of foreign law may be the subject of an order for reference under UCPR r 20.14.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 126] s 126 Rules to prevail over Acts

p.text: [s 126 rep Act 41 of 1972 s 11]
[s 127 rep Act 48 of 1987 s 3 and Sch 32]
[s 128 rep Act 48 of 1987 s 3 and Sch 32]
